newsitem.title: CANADA: Toronto stocks fall one pct, but avoid Dow selloff.
newsitem.headline: Toronto stocks fall one pct, but avoid Dow selloff.

text.p: Toronto stocks avoided following a sharp sell-off on Wall Street, but still fell by more than one percent on Friday, led by heavy losses in banking, transport and conglomerates.
The TSE 300 Composite Index surrendered 71.76 points, or 1.06 percent, to finish at 6695.09.
Nearly 70 million shares were traded worth C$1.22 billion ($877 million).
In New York, the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped by over 247 points, its second biggest point loss ever.
"It's about time. It's way overdue. I think the high multiple stocks are getting hit and momentum is changing a bit," said Montreal-based strategist Bill Ram.
The transport sector was hardest hit, dropping nearly two percent, followed by financial services, conglomerates and base metals.
There were modest gains in gold and precious metals, up 31 points, and consumer products.
Declining stocks battered advances 587 to 368 with 297 issues unchanged.
Ram said there was no specific news to spark today's decline, but a seven to 10 percent correction in the near term would be healthy for equity markets which have soared so high.
* Big name Canadian stocks which tumbled on Friday included Northern Telecom Ltd., off 4 to 136. Imperial Oil Ltd. fell 2 to 72.25, while miner Cameco Corp. lost 2.40 to 50.85.
* Among the banks, Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce lost 0.70 to 37.40, while Bank of Nova Scotia sank 1.40 to 62.30.
Scotiabank completed its C$1.25 million ($899 million) cash and stock deal to acquire National Trustco Inc. on Friday.
* Among conglomerates, Canadian Pacific Ltd. was down 0.60 to 41.85. In transportation, Laidlaw Inc. was off 0.50 to 20.25.
* Cambior Inc. dipped 0.10 to 15.80 after normal operations resumed at its unit Omai Gold Mines Ltd. in Guyana.
